RgeoProfile example - real world data

Michael Stevens

2020-12-03

Data_Rgeoprofile.Rmd

Introduction

In this tutorial, we will walk through another example of running an analysis using the R package, RgeoProfile. The previous example saw us run an analysis on simulated data. This time, we will focus on a real-world data set where we try to infer my home and work location based on where I have used my credit card in London. Similarly to before, this analysis will consist of:

  • Loading and checking our data - we must ensure it's in the correct format for analysis.
  • Setting up the parameters for the model and the MCMC algorithm.
  • Running the MCMC algorithm.
  • Visualising the output of the model

Once again, let's load the package RgeoProfile using library(RgeoProfile).

# load required packages
library(RgeoProfile)  # to run the analysis
library(leaflet)      # to create interactive maps
library(raster)       # for general spatial analysis

Load and check data

The data for this tutorial can be accessed using data(card_crime) and data(card_source). As already mentioned, these data sets consist of a set of longitudinal/latitudinal points and the source locations (also in long/lat format) that are responsible for said "crimes". Let's process our data using the geoData() and geoDataSource() functions to ensure that the data are in the correct format for running the model.

# load the data 
data(card_crime)
data(card_source)

# assign short names to the data for easy access
d <- card_crime
s <- card_source

# convert d and s to correct format for geoParams()
# note that in this case the example data are already in the correct
# format; these steps are only relevant if for example d and s are 
# imported as two-column matrices. They are included here for
# completeness. In the case that d and s are two-column matrices
# the following functions switch them to a `list` format. 

d <- geoData(d$longitude, d$latitude)
s <- geoDataSource(s$longitude, s$latitude)

print(d)
## $longitude
##  [1] -0.071734 -0.076573 -0.070314 -0.050882 -0.051183 -0.046505 -0.045314
##  [8] -0.033403 -0.039491 -0.030891 -0.039573 -0.067394
## 
## $latitude
##  [1] 51.50717 51.50972 51.51366 51.50697 51.52106 51.52186 51.52215 51.52522
##  [9] 51.52762 51.52783 51.52372 51.50698
print(s)
## $longitude
## [1] -0.042032 -0.069717
## 
## $latitude
## [1] 51.52344 51.50978

We can see above that the data are in the correct format. This time, let's visualise our data. It's always worth doing this to get an idea of what we're working with. Mapping our data will give us an indication if anything went wrong when collecting or processing the data.

# plot the map
geoPlotLeaflet(data = d, 
               crimeCex = 6)

At a glance we have a total of 12 locations, seven of which lie in East London, around Mile End, and the other 5 are near Tower Bridge. We might also start thinking about where the source locations are and how many there might be. What do you think? Have a guess. I have purposefully neglected to put the source locations on the map, since in practice we won't know where they are. We might think there are two source locations since the crimes are split between Mile End and Tower Hill. We might alter this guess to three source locations, where the additional source is responsible for the single crime at Shadwell Basin. Similarly to the last tutorial, we do actually possess the source locations linked to the set of crimes shown in the map above. I won't be revealing the right answer (the location of the sources) until the very end of the tutorial. However, it must be stressed that knowing the source locations is not a necessity to run the model.

Build a parameters object

The next step is to build a parameters object for our model. In the previous tutorial we did not discuss the choice of priors we used when running the model. All priors are controlled via the geoParams() function. We control the prior on source locations via the priorMean_longitude, priorMean_latitude and tau. The first two of those arguments set a location where me might think the source(s) could be. By default, this is set to the spatial mean of our crimes, since this is an appropriate place to start looking for source locations. The last of those arguments (tau) controls how strongly we believe source locations are near the priorMean_longitude and priorMean_latitude location. If we set tau quite small then we believe source locations are very near the prior mean. Setting tau quite large will inform the model that source locations are just as likely far away from the mean as they are close to it. Let's look at our map again with the mean plotted as well as our crimes.

As we can see, the spatial mean (in blue) is quite near a few of the crimes, but then again also quite far from others, So this indicates we should set a large tau (in Km). Whether or not tau is a large or small value really depends on the species you are trying to catch. For a human on foot, a large value of tau would be 10 Km, but for elephants a large tau could be 30 Km. Another paramater we are interested in but yet to speak about is the dispersal parameter "sigma". Measured in kilometres, this parameter governs how far away crimes are from source locations. We control this parameter using the sigma_mean and sigma_var arguments. Sigma_mean is the explicit value we think sigma could be and sigma_var controls our uncertainty in this value. For a human roaming around committing crimes on foot this value will be much smaller than those that have access to a car. Equivalently if a criminal is time restricted (committing crimes on a lunch break for example) this value may be much lower. In ecology, we might expect quite small values of sigma for mosquitoes but much larger values for tigers. It really depends if you are analysing data associated with a human or an animal etc. Since we are conisdering a human moving around on foot, we shall set our prior accordingly.

# assign an object that sets the model and MCMC parameters
# name the object p (short for parameters)
# we believe the majority of crimes are within 1km of the source location
# hence we set the mean of sigma to 0.25 km, and the variance to 1, to ensure our
# prior distirbution on sigma is up to 1km. 
 
p <- geoParams(data = d,      
               tau = 10,          # set tau large (10 kilometres) for source locations in any location
               sigma_mean = 0.25, # mean value of sigma
               sigma_var = 1,     # our uncertainty in the value of sigma
               chains = 5, 
               burnin = 1e4, 
               samples = 5e4,
               longitude_cells = 200, 
               latitude_cells = 200, 
               guardRail = 0.5,
               burnin_printConsole = 1e3, 
               samples_printConsole = 1e4)
## Using sigma_mean and sigma_var to define prior on sigma

Now that we have built our parameters object, we can visualise our prior on sigma using the geoPlotSigma() function. When we refer to a prior we are talking about a probability distribution that captures our beliefs regarding which values our parameter could take. So here, we are describing our prior on sigma, the distribution that describes which values of sigma are more likely than others.

# plot sigma prior
geoPlotSigma(params = p, plotMax  = 3)

Here we can see our prior distribution on sigma. The Y axis shows the probability of observing different values of sigma. We stated that our sigma_mean = 0.25 hence the mean of the distribution is around 0.25 km. We also set sigma_var = 1, i.e. how much we are willing for sigma to deviate from our mean. We can also see that the probability of observing a tiny sigma (less than 0.05 km) is zero, and a large sigma (greater than 1.5 km) is also zero.

Run the model

Once again, we run the model using the geoMCMC() function. We provide this function with our data and our params.

# run MCMC
m <- geoMCMC(data = d, params = p)
## data file passed all checks
## params file passed all checks
## 
## Initiating burn-in phase (5 chains)
##     convergence at the GR=1.1 level reached within 100 iterations
##   iteration: 1000
##   iteration: 2000
##   iteration: 3000
##   iteration: 4000
##   iteration: 5000
##   iteration: 6000
##   iteration: 7000
##   iteration: 8000
##   iteration: 9000
##   iteration: 10000
##     final GR statistic: GR=1.02549
## 
## Initiating sampling phase
##   iteration: 10000
##   iteration: 20000
##   iteration: 30000
##   iteration: 40000
##   iteration: 50000
## 
## MCMC completed in 0.718 seconds
## Smoothing posterior surface...........
## maximum likelihood lambda = 0.056

Here we can see the model stating how far through the burn in and sampling phases it is. Notice the burn in phase states that the five MCMC chains have all converged to the same answer within 100 iterations using our chosen metric for MCMC convergence (the Gelamn-Rubin diagnostic (Gelman, Hwang, and Vehtari (2014))). The sampling phase then ends with a "maximum likelihood lambda". You can ignore this value as it is automatically chosen to create an accurate geoprofile (but more details can be found in Barnard (2010)).

Visualise output

Let's have a look at our geographic profile. Again, we generate the geographic profile using the geoPlotLeaflet() function. The main things we must provide to this function are the params and the raw geoprofile produced by the model. Hence we provide these using the params and surface arguments.

# plot geoprofile on the map using geoPlotLeaflet
# We access the geoprofile from within the m object using the $ sign
geoPlotLeaflet(surface = m$geoProfile,                # access the geoprofile                  
               params = p,                            # add in params object    
               data = d,                              # add in data
               surfaceCols = rev(viridis::plasma(10)),# set the colours of the profile
               opacity = 0.7,                         # set the opacity of the surface
               threshold = 0.25,                      # plot the top 25% of the profile
               crimeCex = 5,                          # set the size of the crimes
               gpLegend = TRUE)                       # add a legend for the hit score

We have our geoprofile! As mentioned in the previous tutorials, areas in yellow are the places we should prioritize our search strategy with areas in purple indicating areas unlikely to contain source locations. Intuitively we can see the model telling us to search in those areas near Tower Bridge and Mile end. In addition to these two clusters there seems to be some search priority aimed at the spatial mean of the crime sites too. Finally, we can see the model also places a small amount of priority near the lone crime in Shadwell Basin. Before we add the source locations to the map and measure their hit scores, let's have a look at our estimate for sigma. This can be plotted by adding the mcmc argument into the geoPlotSigma() function.

# plot sigma prior
geoPlotSigma(params = p, 
             plotMax  = 3,
             mcmc = m)

Now we can see our prior and posterior distributions for the dispersal parameter sigma. We have already discussed our prior distribution but our posterior distribution tells a very different story. The posterior distribution combines the information we provide in the prior distribution with the information gained from the data we provide. The main peak of the posterior distribution on sigma is around 0.45 km. Curiously though, the distribution is bi-modal, it has two peaks. This indicates the criminal might have two modes of transport, on foot and perhaps by bike.

Let's reveal the location of the source locations on the map

# plot the same map again, this time providing source locations 
# using the source argument
geoPlotLeaflet(surface = m$geoProfile,
               params = p,
               data = d, 
               source = s,             # include sources this time 
               sourceCex = 5,
               sourceCol = "black",
               surfaceCols = rev(viridis::plasma(10)),
               opacity = 0.7,
               threshold = 0.25,
               crimeCex = 5,
               gpLegend = TRUE)

Once again, remember that we won't normally have these source locations, they are provided here to display the accuracy of geographic profiling. Our model seems to working well, all source locations (in black) are all landing in yellow areas. Looking at the map gives us a quick indication of how well our model is doing but let's go back to the hit score and Gini co-efficent metrics using the the geoReportHitscores() and geoPlotLorenz() functions.

# get hitscores
hs <- geoReportHitscores(params = p, 
                         source = s, 
                         surface = m$geoProfile)
hs
##   latitude longitude     hs
## 1 51.52344 -0.042032 0.1675
## 2 51.50978 -0.069717 0.7475
# produce Lorenz plot
Gini <- geoPlotLorenz(hit_scores = hs)

print(Gini)
## G_sources 
##     0.995

We can see that the geoReportHitscores() function provides us with our source locations and a corresponding hit score. This is excellent! Our hit scores for each source are less than 1%! So in order to find the source locations, we only need to search less than 1% of the total search area to find them. Equivalently, the Gini co-efficient for these sources is 0.995, remeber that the most efficent search strategy would yield a Gini co-efficient of 1.
